author: kolbyml
content:
Ethereum Portal History Network 4444â€™s FAQ <https://notes.ethereum.org/@Kolby-ML/HJ-9D5aYp>
Here is the FAQ I read a bit of today. If anyone has questions I can answer them and add them here

author: _shemnon
content: For eip-7523 - do we add it to a fork like the SELFDESTRUCT deprecation EIP got? (EIP-6049).  A no-op for clients but formalizing it via process.

author: chfast
content: This is different and does not affect users / contract devs.

author: _shemnon
content: It impacts EVMs.  If an evm drops pre-merge versions they don't have to worry about ghost empty accounts.

author: _shemnon
content: Also we can sunset some reference tests.

author: chfast
content:
The [EIP-7523](https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-7523) by <@243183686562873344>  gives guarantee that there are no empty accounts in the state.
The EVM is not able to create empty accounts since ages. But there way to have them in the state is by initial state configuration (tests, devnets, testnets, etc).

Actions needed:
- update tests, https://github.com/ethereum/tests/issues/1331
- validate pre-state in clients
- move the EIP to "review"

author: peter.davies
content: Honestly quite a lot of reference tests, see my PR (https://github.com/ethereum/tests/pull/1329). A reasonable amount of spec time is wasted on dealing with new account clearing edgecases.

author: chfast
content: The EIP is still a draft so I didn't know there was any discussion about it in ACDE

author: _shemnon
content: I recognize the names of some of those tests in that PR.  The kind of recognition that triggers my fight or flight reflexes.

author: timbeiko
content:
**ACDE Recap**
- **Dencun:** The Sepolia fork went very well overall! Prysm is investigating a proposal delay issue that may be due to relays. That said, the Nethermind team managed to break devnet-12 using a blob spammer. Over the next week, we'll dig into both of these issues, see blobs expire on Goerli, and have Holesky fork. Assuming everything looks by then, we'll pick a mainnet fork time on next week's ACDC. By then, we'll also try and gather testing feedback from L2s. 
- Most of the call went into details for Verkle, EOF, and EIP-4444/Portal. I won't recap all the conversations here, but here are a few notable links:
 - Verkle status update: https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1R_UkS0WyGN1FK3qYxSBK5zZxBbN8Cx2mFHQj6rQ0jRA/edit?usp=sharing 
- Portal FAQ: https://notes.ethereum.org/@Kolby-ML/HJ-9D5aYp
- **We agreed to prioritize Verkle and make it the core feature of the Osaka upgrade, which will follow Prague**. I've opened a PR to reflect this: https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/8159 
- With that decided, we'll focus the next ACDE on finalizing the scope for Prague: https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/8121
- No objections to reserving a precompile range for L2s, so https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/8074 will move forward. 
- Lastly, two things we didn't get to cover on the call but want to flag: 
1. Adding client versions in the Engine API: https://github.com/ethereum/execution-apis/pull/517
2. EIP-7523, see: https://discord.com/channels/595666850260713488/745077610685661265/1202638134928740484

author: kolbyml
content: Check out <#953349957400821860> I will post a link to the era1 PR there which has the details. era is a format for post merge beacon data (I don't believe it stores EL bodies or receipts, it stores beacon block bodies). era1 is for pre-merge EL history
